title: Pauline Hanson is wrong. Nobody is having kids for the money, writes Lauren Martyn-Jones | The Courier-Mail
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search The meeting place for news-making views Lauren Martyn-Jones If you’re having kids for the cash you’re more likely to go broke than get rich 
DECIDING to start trying for kids is a massive decision which usually requires a fair bit of deliberation. If you think women are getting pregnant for the government payments, you’ve obviously never checked the price of a modern pram. (Pic: Steve Tanner) 
DECIDING to start trying for kids is a massive decision which usually requires a fair bit of deliberation. 
Is the timing right? What impact will it have on my career? Am I/we in a position to be able to do this, both financially and emotionally? 
My husband and I went through all of this last year when we decided we wanted to expand our little family. 
We had long chats (usually over a bottle of the kind of pinot noir I’ve been missing ever since falling pregnant) about what we wanted our future to look like, and how we might juggle all of the moving pieces in our busy lives. 
And yet, at no point did the financial windfall of government benefits enter the equation. 
This week Pauline Hanson came out against the federal government’s omnibus welfare bill, declaring it was problematic because the Coalition’s less-than-extravagant paid parental leave policy just encourages opportunistic women to breed. Other Stories
